Diabetes goes far beyond excessive sugar consumption.

Diabetes management is not just about controlling sugar, carbohydrate intake also plays a vital role. When the body processes carbohydrates, they break down into glucose, elevating blood sugar levels and potentially accelerating kidney damage.

Nearly 40% of people with Type 2 Diabetes (#T2D) develop Chronic Kidney Disease (#CKD). But, early detection and healthier lifestyle choices can make all the difference. The Urine Albumin-Creatinine Ratio (#UACR) test can detect elevated albumin levels, an early indicator of kidney complications, supporting timely intervention and treatment.

Switching to low-carbohydrate diets, staying active, and getting regular health checks are powerful steps toward protecting kidney health and improving overall well-being.

With over 89 million adults living with diabetes in India alone, many remain undiagnosed. Together with Diabetes India, Bayer's nationwide CHECK campaign aims to screen 100,000 T2D patients using the UACR test.

This #WorldDiabetesDay, it's all about CHECKing in time, and protecting in time.

#BayerIndia #CheckKidneys #DiabetesCare #PreventionMatters #HealthAorAll

Another milestone achieved!

We are proud to share that Bayer Vapi has been awarded the Responsible Care Logo Certification by the Indian Chemical Council (ICC), a globally recognized accreditation for maintaining the highest standards of safety, health, environmental protection, and security across all operations.

This recognition follows a comprehensive three-day audit conducted by three well-experienced ICC auditors, who evaluated our HSE systems, process safety, waste and energy management, and emergency preparedness. 

With this recertification, Bayer Vapi continues to be among the 93 Responsible Care logo-holding members of the Indian Chemical Council. More than a certification, the Responsible Care accreditation reflects the dedication and collective effort of every Bayer Vapi team member. 

Receiving this recognition for the third consecutive cycle reaffirms Bayerâ€™s unwavering commitment to continuous improvement, responsible operations, and sustainable value creation for society.

Health as the foundation of Africaâ€™s growth ğŸŒğŸ’Š

Without healthy citizens, no economy can be sustainable.
Across the continent, policymakers are increasingly aligning around a shared conviction:
health must be recognised as an investment, not a cost, and as the foundation of resilient and inclusive development.

The numbers tell a clear story. Africa has only 3% of the worldâ€™s health workers while bearing more than 24% of the world's disease burden.
More than 50% of Africans still lack access to essential health services. And stroke - being part of the top leading causes of death deserves attention.

By 2030, non-communicable diseases are projected to overtake infectious diseases as the leading cause of death.

The implications are both human and economic.

For the private sector, this is not just a moral imperative â€” it is a strategic opportunity to invest in the continentâ€™s human capital and long-term growth.
Some companies are already taking this path.

Among them, Bayer stands out for its science-driven commitment to cardiovascular and renal health in Sub-Saharan Africa:

ğŸ’ŠÂ providing innovative therapies for chronic kidney disease in Type 2 diabetes,
ğŸ©ºÂ training healthcare professionals on stroke prevention and management,
ğŸ“¦Â improving treatment availability for non-communicable diseases**, and
ğŸŒÂ supporting awareness and screening programmes that enable early detection.

The principle of harm reduction captures the essence of this shift:
instead of denying or punishing vulnerabilities, it addresses them pragmatically, preserving life while enabling individuals and communities to move forward and grow.

Africaâ€™s health transformation is therefore not just a public good â€” itâ€™s a growth frontier for investors, innovators, and policymakers alike.
Because empowering health systems means strengthening economies.

At Bayer, we recognize that sustainability is essential for our future, and we are committed to harnessing the potential of young talent to drive impactful change. This commitment is exemplified by our participation in the One Young World Summit 2025, taking place in Munich, Germany, from November 3rd to 6th. This esteemed global forum gathers young leaders to discuss and tackle pressing global issues. Key topics this year include the Circular Economy, Anti-Hate, Responsible Tech, Education, Peace and Security. 

We are thrilled to announce that our dedicated young delegates from around the world will facilitate a workshop titled "Engaging Next Generations in Menopause Conversations." This initiative aims to foster an open dialogue about menopause, dispel myths, and create a supportive environment for learning about the challenges and opportunities associated with this natural life stage.

Through this workshop, we aspire to engage OYW delegates in meaningful conversations about menopause, empowering them to become advocates for women's health.

By raising awareness and encouraging open discussions, we aim to break down barriers and create a more informed and supportive community around this important topic.

Join us in championing women's health and well-being at the One Young World Summit! Together, we can make a difference.

Menopause is a chapter in life that many women enter quietly, yet itâ€™s a life-changing transition that deserves open conversations.

A global survey of women found that only 20 percent of women feel well-informed about menopause.  Symptoms like hot flashes, sleep disturbances, mood swings, and memory lapses are often endured in silence, leaving many women feeling lost or invisible. 

That's why discussions between women and healthcare providers are crucial to finding meaningful solutions for symptoms. 

At #TeamBayer, we are committed to supporting women on this journey. Together, we can change the narrative â€“ from silence and stigma to openness and support. It is time to amplify the many voices and experiences, ensuring every woman can feel seen, heard, and empowered.

Did you know? Individuals with chronic kidney disease (CKD) associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D) are three times more likely to die from a cardiovascular (CV) event compared to those with T2D alone.

Over time, elevated blood sugar levels can damage blood vessels, including those in the kidneys. This often leads to albuminuria (a protein found in urine), which serves as an early warning sign of deteriorating kidney health and a risk factor for CV disease, including heart failure.

But hereâ€™s the good news: a simple urine test can identify albuminuria early, before significant harm occurs.

Thatâ€™s why #TeamBayer is raising awareness. Regular testing and early detection in at-risk individuals can significantly impact the protection of both kidney and heart health.

#Type2Diabetes #ChronicKidneyDisease

Have you ever considered that your heart continuously pumps 5 liters of blood every single day â€“ an extraordinary organ! However, when it's damaged or under strain, its ability to function can be compromised.

ğŸ§¬TTR or prealbumin plays a crucial role in the transport of vitamin A and thyroid hormone in the body. In some cases, due to an inherited mutation or aging, TTR falls apart, misfolds, and the smaller pieces then clump together, forming amyloid fibrils that accumulate in the heart. This condition is known as transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy (ATTR-CM) and eventually leads to serious complications such as heart failure.

By raising awareness and improving early recognition, we can change outcomes for those living with this fatal disease. #TeamBayer is committed to improving care for the ATTR-CM community.

#Cardiology #ESC2025

In a world facing changing climates and growing food demands, we need innovative solutions for farmers to sustainably put enough food on our plates. 

Enter digital twin technology ğŸŒ± ğŸŒ± â€” a groundbreaking technology that allows us to digitally replicate plants and fields, ensuring our seeds fit environments, conditions, and needs before they hit the soil.

Over 100 million people in India live with diabetes and the number continues to grow. Whatâ€™s less known is that diabetes is a major cause of #ChronicKidneyDisease or #CKD, which can develop quietly, without noticeable symptoms.
 
The #UACR (Urine Albumin-to-Creatinine Ratio) test is a simple, non-invasive urine test that helps detect early #kidney damage and potential #cardiovascular risks. It measures albumin, a protein that signals kidney stress, especially in those with diabetes.
 
If you or someone you know is living with diabetes, talk to a healthcare provider about the UACR test. Early detection is key to protecting #KidneyHealth.

Always consult your healthcare professional for further guidance.

#BayerIndia #DiabetesCare

The future of Indian agriculture is being redefined not just through #innovation, but through integration. At the 16th Agriculture Leadership Conclave 2025, #Bayer leaders outlined what it will take to build a future-ready #farming ecosystem. He shared insights on how advanced tech can be adapted to suit Indian realities through remote sensing, AI-driven agronomic insights and localised predictive analytics.

Together, these innovations help make advice actionable, precise, and scalable, even for small and fragmented farms.

EU Approval for Extended Treatment Intervals

The European Commission has approved extended treatment intervals of up to six months for a treatment option for retinal diseases, like neovascular age-related macular degeneration (nAMD) and diabetic macular edema (DME). This aims to reduce injection frequency, and improve patient adherence.

Retinal diseases such as nAMD and DME can lead to vision loss if untreated. The long treatment intervals offer hope for better management of these diseases.

As the global population ages and diabetes prevalence increases, effective treatments are crucial in combating vision loss and blindness. This approval represents a significant step forward in addressing these unmet medical needs, offering improved management options for patients worldwide.

Learn more: https://lnkd.in/ekY-krjA

Flattening organizations is everywhere in the news, but it's usually just cost-cutting dressed up as transformation. As Bill Anderson, CEO of Bayer, said in an interview published by The New York Times Dealbook, that approach misses the point entirely.

"Most corporate change programs take out heads but not the work," Anderson explained. "They eliminate a layer â€” usually just one â€” and leave everything else the same. People are back two years later because the work still has to get done."

Bayer's taking a different approach. They eliminated five layers of management and pushed average span of control from 5 direct reports to nearly 15. When you're responsible for that many people, you can't micromanage anymore. You have to become more of a mentor and coach instead of a controller.

Anderson and colleagues are also reimagining core processes like resource allocation. Bayer's annual budget process has been scrapped. Instead of spending months on bureaucratic planning, teams now spend one day every 90 days asking: How did we do? What's next? Who do we need? Then they work for 89 days. When Bayer's contraception team needed to win back a major client, they made all the resource decisions themselvesâ€”brought in specialists, added medical liaisonsâ€”without going up through management layers.

The company's also overhauling HR systems, moving to peer-based performance reviews and scrapping hierarchy-based job grading.

ğŸ‘‰ The lesson: to bust bureaucracy, you need to be bold enough to imagine radical alternatives and systematic enough to change all aspects of workâ€”hierarchy, processes, and decision rights together.

Great reporting by Aimee Groth!

How is Science in Agriculture Empowering Smallholder Farmers in Zambia?

In Zambia, maize isn't just foodâ€”it's livelihood. That's why our expanded seed production facility in this beautiful nation is a game-changer for millions of smallholder farmers.
The innovation lies in our approach to hybrid seed technology:
â€¢ We examine the DNA of millions of seeds 
â€¢ We cross them to create customized hybrids 
â€¢ We select for optimal yield, drought tolerance, and plant resilience

The impact? Farmers who previously struggled with inconsistent yields from open-pollinated varieties are now harvesting 5,000-10,000 kg per hectare â€” that is enough to feed their families AND sell surplus crops.

As one local farmer told our CEO, Bill Anderson, during his visit: "I treasure the scientists because they're doing a great job. Having a hybrid variety properly defined with good growth gives me courage and heart to work hard."

This is the essence of our mission: using cutting-edge science to create tangible improvements in food security and economic opportunity for those who need it most.

With more than 2 million new cases each year, breast cancer is the most common cancer in women globally. More than two-thirds of breast cancers are hormone-receptor positive. For this type of breast cancer endocrine therapy is the well-established standard, which often comes with typical menopause side effects like severe hot flashes. 

These symptoms can make life challenging and even decrease treatment adherence, which may increase recurrence rates and worsen long-term outcomes.

At Bayer, we are dedicated to address important unmet medical needs, developing tailored therapies that improve women's lives.

ğŸ§¬ Could the future of CRISPR result in a Multi-Billion Dollar Market? Nobel Prize winner Jennifer Doudna thinks it could be!

Juergen Eckhardt, Head of Leaps by Bayer recently discussed the transformative potential of #CRISPR technology with Jennifer Doudna, who co-developed this method for gene editing. 
The CRISPR space is developing at a rapid pace. The first FDA-approved CRISPR therapy for sickle cell disease has rolled out and Doudna remains optimistic about gene editing's future.

Key insights from the Magazine Forbes article: 
     - The first CRISPR therapy, approved by the Food and Drug Administration at the end of 2023, can effectively cure a disease that was once untreatable. 
     - Clinical pipelines are advancing rapidly, with Intellia Therapeutics achieving effective in vivo editing with a single injection
     - CRISPR treatments are showing remarkable results - reducing bad cholesterol by up to 80% in early trials 
     - The biggest technical challenge isn't CRISPR itself but delivery systems for the enzymes
Beyond medicine, Doudna is particularly bullish on CRISPR's impact in agriculture, where her team is working on reducing methane emissions from cows and developing drought-resistant rice.

But there are obstacles slowing things down. Hereâ€™s what is needed next for CRISPR to make an even bigger impact on the world: 
     - Regulatory frameworks that embrace CRISPR as a platform technology 
     - Renewed investor confidence (currently in the "reality check" phase of the biotech hype cycle) 
     - Continued support for basic, curiosity-driven research

As Doudna noted, "Innovation comes a lot of times from just studying things that initially don't have a connection to what you want to do, but in the end, you find out they are connected."

Eckhardt sees the value in investing in this innovation as well. Leaps by Bayer has invested in companies that use gene editing across health and agriculture, such as Pairwise, eGenesis, Inc. , Capstan Therapeutics, and Metagenom Bio Life Science because their work also aligns with our mission towards #HealthForAll #HungerForNone.

What do you think? How can you envision CRISPR transforming agriculture and healthcare in the next decade? Share your thoughts below ğŸ‘‡

The Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use (CHMP) of the European Medicines Agency (EMA) has issued a positive opinion on eye medication with extended treatment intervals.

Once approved, this can mean for patients and their caregivers less injections and clinic visits, opening capacity for ophthalmologists to treat more patients.

nAMD and DME are conditions that can severely affect individuals' vision if left untreated, leading to challenges in performing everyday activities and diminishing quality of life.

Heart failure is often overlooked, yet it poses a significant challenge to global health, affecting over 64 million people worldwide. Despite advancements in care, individuals with heart failure face survival outcomes comparable to or worse than those diagnosed with some common cancers. 

This serious condition weakens the heartâ€™s ability to pump blood effectively, leading to debilitating symptoms like fatigue and shortness of breath, which can hinder daily activities. 

Early recognition saves lives. With each heart failure event requiring hospitalization, residual risks increase, making it crucial to identify signs and symptoms early on.

In line with our mission of #HealthForAll, #HungerForNone, #TeamBayer stands in solidarity with the European Society of Cardiology in our shared goal: reducing the impact of heart failure and empowering patients to reclaim their lives. Together, weâ€™re committed to advancing awareness, transforming perceptions, and driving change.

It's a fact: Our health and well-being are shaped by our circumstances and surroundings, whether by chance or by choice. Our Research Initiative for Self-Care Equity (RISE) reveals the powerful impact of socioeconomic factors on health and highlights the opportunities to help individuals, caregivers, and healthcare professionals drive real change. 

RISE emphasizes the need for personalized self-care solutions, particularly for underserved communities. By understanding the importance of key factors like income and education, we are better equipped to help globally address health issues like malnutrition, anemia, pain, allergies, and intimate health in communities. By combining research, innovative solutions, policy advocacy, and community engagement, weâ€™re on a mission to make quality healthcare accessible for everyone

This commitment aligns perfectly with #TeamBayer's mission of #HealthForAll and #HungerForNone, paving the way for improved health outcomes for all, regardless of their socioeconomic background.

Together, we can make a lasting impact to help people thrive, raise healthier families, and build better lives.  #HealthEquity

Weâ€™re focusing on Upper Egypt and Frontier Governorates, where the need is greatest.

This extension supports Bayerâ€™s â€œHealth for all, Hunger for Noneâ€ missionâ€, and our commitment to providing 100 million women in low- and middle-income countries with access to modern contraception by 2030 and UNFPA's vision of universal access to voluntary family planning.

In addition, it also contributes towards the UNFPA Strategic Plan (2022-2025) and reaching zero unmet need for family planning, thus contributing to UNFPAâ€™s transformative results.

Clean water is now closer to home!

Bayer, in partnership with Safe Water Network, has launched the #iJal initiative to provide safe drinking water to communities in water-stressed areas across #Karnataka, #Maharashtra, #Gujarat, and #Telangana, benefitting 270,000 people.

Building on the success of the iJal Station launched last month in Chandippa, Telangana, Bayer recently inaugurated the first of 20 planned #iJal stations in Karnataka at Chikkaballapur. This is part of a larger initiative to set up 90 iJal stations across India, focused on fostering community health, economic empowerment, and social development.

The #WaterATMs are designed to empower local communities by involving #SelfHelpGroups (SHGs) and entrepreneurs, mostly women, creating local employment and ensuring the modelâ€™s long-term sustainability.

Equipped with advanced filtration and remote monitoring systems, the iJal stations will deliver clean water at affordable rates through a prepaid RFID card system, promoting efficient and equitable usage.

Because clean water isnâ€™t a privilege, itâ€™s a right.

This #WorldHealthDay, we draw attention to a growing health crisis: anemia.

In India, a staggering 52.2% of pregnant women between the ages of 15-49 are affected by this condition. When iron levels drop, the risk of anemia rises significantly, especially during pregnancy. This deficiency can lead to severe consequences, including low birth weight, impaired brain development, and a weaker start in life for babies.

At Bayer, we believe every woman deserves the right to proper nutrition. Because healthier mothers mean stronger, healthier generations.
 
#BayerIndia #BayerForWomen #HealthForAll #HungerForNone #MaternalHealth #IronDeficiency #Anemia

By 2030, more than 1 billion women will be in menopause. Menopause can substantially affect a womanâ€™s life, but a lack of awareness and care options leaves most symptoms untreated. Each womanâ€™s experience with the menopause transition will be different. 

Menopause usually begins during a period where women are at the peak of their lifeâ€™s activity and can affect them both at home and in the workplace -- and it is much more than JUST hot flashes. In fact, the most commonly reported and bothersome symptoms during the menopausal transition are hot flashes, sleep disturbances, and mood changes. 

From developing therapeutic options that address menopause symptoms to global physician education efforts, weâ€™re actively broadening womenâ€™s options for care that help them maintain their health and quality of life through this transition.

Forget the old career playbook â€” work hard, stay put, and follow a straight path. The world of work is evolving, and so should our thinking.

At Bayer, we believe careers arenâ€™t set in stone â€” theyâ€™re built dynamically, shaped by collaboration, learning, and taking ownership of what matters most. So, letâ€™s rethink some outdated career advice:

1.	â€Your degree defines your career."
Reality check: Many people end up working in fields completely unrelated to their degree. Skills, adaptability, and experience matter way more than your major. Many of us at Bayer have taken unexpected, exciting career turns!

2.	"You have to say yes to every opportunity."
True impact comes from focusing on where you can contribute most. Itâ€™s not about saying yes to everything â€” itâ€™s about making bold, intentional choices.

3.	"Job hopping looks bad on a rÃ©sumÃ©."
Not anymore! The world is changing, and so is how we grow. Gaining diverse experiences â€” inside and outside one role or company â€” builds valuable perspectives that help us shape the future together.

4.	â€œA stable 9-to-5 is the safest career choice."
Stability isnâ€™t just about a traditional job anymore. New working time models and digital careers offer flexibility and new opportunities that traditional jobs canâ€™t always provide.

5.	â€œYou need to have your entire career path figured out in your 20s."
Nope! Careers arenâ€™t a straight line. The best growth happens when we stay curious, keep learning, and take ownership of our path â€” wherever it leads.

The truth is: Thereâ€™s no single "right" way to build a career. The key is to stay adaptable, keep learning, and create a path that works for you.

Which of these career myths have you believed before? Or do you have one to add to the list? Drop it in the comments!

#TeamBayer #BayerCareer #CareerMyths #BeBayer

What comes to mind when you think about 'healthy aging'?  

Perhaps you think about a healthy diet, staying fit through movement and sport. Perhaps it is through being proactive by going to your health care provider. But there are also many other aspects that contribute to healthy aging that you might not realize play such a big role like governmental policies, education, the social aspect of community and support systems, even climate change!  

We are grateful to everyone working in these areas across R&D, academia, science, medicine, government affairs, and more all contributing to this important cause. Because as a life science company, we canâ€™t just work in a silo and expect to make a positive and lasting impact on society. We need to look at healthy aging and innovative pharmaceutical advancements holistically. 

Thank you to all the partners around the world, with whom we work with â€“ or hope to work with in the future - to help the next generations live a longer, healthier life!

Water resilience begins with heroes like Shanti Lata Basiwal, who turned adversity into opportunity.

When labor shortages, erratic rainfall, and rising costs threatened her familyâ€™s farmland in Odisha, India, Shanti made a bold choice. She left a stable town business to protect her communityâ€™s lifelineâ€”rice farming.

Refusing to give up, Shanti became an inspiration for her people. She adopted Direct Seeded Rice (DSR), reducing labor dependency and water usage. Traditional rice farming consumes 4,000â€“5,000 liters of water per kilogram, but DSR cuts water use by 40%, lowers methane emissions by 45%, and enhances soil healthâ€”securing livelihoods in the process.

With 150 million smallholder farmers worldwide, DSR has the potential to make rice cultivation sustainable. At Bayer, we are promoting water-smart agricultural practices to help farmers grow more and restore more.

Click here to know more about Shanti's inspiring story: https://lnkd.in/gZvskhAV

Populations in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) are particularly vulnerable to the health effects of climate change due to their geographical location, low socioeconomic status and weak healthcare infrastructure. In this context, climate change disproportionately affects women and girls, exacerbating existing gender inequalities and posing distinct health risks.  

As a leader in womenâ€™s health and agriculture, we at Bayer are supporting women to give them access to the tools and knowledge to improve their health, rights and economic status. In doing so, we can also lay the foundation for and support future generations of women.

Since our humble beginnings in 1863 with the development of synthetic dyes, Bayer has been at the forefront of innovation. From our groundbreaking launch of Aspirin in 1899 to our tailored solutions for women's health in 2024, we reflect our unwavering commitment to pushing the boundaries of whatâ€™s possible. Throughout our journey, our dedication to advancing healthcare has remained central to our mission, driving us to achieve groundbreaking results.

We asked scientists to talk about their innovative workâ€“ and asked #AI to visualize it. Watch as Anoop Mohan shares his teamâ€™s passion behind their latest agricultural groundbreaker - Direct Seeded Rice (DSR). 

DSR is kinder to the planet and more beneficial to farmers compared to traditional rice cultivating practices. Replacing flooded paddies with direct-seeded fields has several benefits: DSR reduces the consumption of water and decreases greenhouse gas emissions. It also reduces farmers' reliance on costly labor.

Reminder: Donâ€™t wait until youâ€™re completely exhausted to take a break. Regular breaks help to keep your focus sharp, prevent burnout, and can actually make you more productive. So instead of running on empty, plan your breaks before you need them.

At Bayer, we are dedicated to enabling support for our employees in tailoring to be able to adjust their working day to their individual needs, for example, by offering flexibility in terms of working hours, but also when and how they take their breaks.

Do you have a break routine? Let us know in the comments!

At Bayer, we believe that collaboration is the key to addressing the challenges in agriculture and ensuring a secure, sustainable food future. Our Food Value Chain Partnerships bring together farmers, food processors, retailers, and other stakeholders to create a resilient food value chain that benefits both producers and consumers.  

In India, Bayer has established 60+ FVC Partnerships across 16 crops, enhancing agricultural productivity, quality, and sustainability. Through these collaborations, we empower smallholder farmers with:  
- Assured market access and profitability through buy-back agreements,  
- Sustainable farming practices that improve soil health and water conservation,  
- Expert guidance and digital tools to enhance productivity and market linkages.  

By fostering strong partnerships, we are not only strengthening farming communities but also ensuring a more sustainable and secure food supply for the future. Together, we can drive meaningful change in agriculture.  

#BayerIndia #FoodValueChainPartnerships #SustainableAgriculture #FarmersFirst #FVC

Just a year later, the TUS 04 sports club was founded, kicking off a long tradition of company sports at Bayer.

Regular movement helps reduce stress, increase concentration, and boost energy levels â€“ things we all need in our daily work lives. Thatâ€™s why we provide employees with MyHealth, a platform that offers personalized wellbeing resources and energy workshops that focus on sustainable energy management.

Did you know some of the worldâ€™s most important crops like corn, wheat, and rice require nitrogen fertilizers to become food for our growing population? That's because the microbes on their roots canâ€™t turn the nitrogen in the air into a form they can absorb. Plants like soy, however, have microbes that can do just that. 

What if we could give other crops that same ability? It could save farmers time and money, plus help our planet by conserving precious resources. Thatâ€™s the future of agriculture, and our team is working to make it a reality. 

Together with Ginkgo Bioworks weâ€™re designing microbes to help plants like corn, wheat, and rice fix environmental nitrogen, rather than rely on synthetic fertilizers. This is a big step toward our vision of regenerative agricultureâ€”where farming not only produces more, but also gives back to nature.

What you might think is just dirt is actually soilâ€”and that distinction matters! Climate change is largely driven by excess greenhouse gases, with carbon being a major contributor. But did you know this same carbon can become a valuable resource for a farmerâ€™s soil?

In agriculture, cover crops are off-season plants that protect soil from erosion and pull carbon underground, enhancing its health. Traditionally, their benefits ended there, as they werenâ€™t harvested or sold.

CoverCressâ„¢ changes this by providing all the benefits of traditional cover crops while also being harvestable for renewable fuel with ultra-low carbon emissions. Itâ€™s a win-win for farmers and nature, turning sustainable practices into smart business opportunities.

Together with the Bayer Foundation and PULA we announce a partnership to provide insurance for 10 million smallholder farmers 

According to the FAO, in 2023, around 2.33 billion people globally faced food insecurity, with smallholder farmers playing a crucial role by producing over half of the food consumed in low- and middle-income countries. However, climate change poses significant challenges to their livelihoods. To address this, the PULA Foundation has created scalable, data-driven agricultural insurance solutions that mitigate risks from extreme weather events such as droughts and floods, ensuring that farmers receive financial compensation. This support enables them to recover, reinvest, and build resilience against climate uncertainties.

By 2030, the Bayer Foundationâ€™s grant for insurance premium supportâ€”backed by a donation from Bayer | Crop Science â€” will unlock potential insurance coverage of 127 million US dollars for 10 million farmers working with national governments in Bangladesh, Pakistan, Malawi, Ghana, Nigeria, Kenya, and Mali.

ğŸŒ± Sustainability Through Innovation: 75% believe genomic techniques can help address climate change and world hunger.

ğŸ“Š Transparency is Key: Only 40% of respondents feel companies are clear about risks and opportunities, underscoring the importance of honest dialogue.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women globally, with over 2 million new cases each year. 

More than two-thirds of breast cancers are hormone-receptor positive which means they have receptors for estrogen or progesterone. While adjuvant endocrine therapy is the well-established standard treatment for this type of breast cancer, it often comes with side effects like severe hot flashes. These symptoms can make life challenging and even decrease treatment adherence, which may increase recurrence rates and worsen long-term outcomes.

At Bayer, we are committed to advancing innovative solutions for women with diverse needs. We are excited to announce positive topline results in the first pivotal international Phase III study in VMS caused by adjuvant endocrine therapy in women being treated or at high risk for breast cancer. This study underscores our dedication to address important unmet medical needs, developing tailored therapies that improve women's lives.

As we move forward, we remain focused on bringing this potential new treatment option to market, ensuring that women have access to effective management strategies for their individual symptoms. Our ongoing dedication to womenâ€™s health reflects our mission to empower women to live their lives to the fullest, regardless of the challenges they face.

Together, letâ€™s continue to pave the way for a healthier future for women everywhere. 

Learn more: bit.ly/News_Bayer

ğŸŒ¾ Can we grow more with less? Yes! And one way is with agricultural practices like Direct Seeded Rice. 

India is home to the worldâ€™s largest rice acreage. It is also at the heart of a global challenge: climate change and its impact on global food security.  

With over half the world's population relying on rice as a daily food staple, regenerative agricultural practices like Direct Seeded Rice (DSR) are crucial. Hereâ€™s why: 

     ğŸŒ Climate impact â†’ Flooded paddy fields, traditionally used to grow rice, not only use a lot of water, they also emit 12% of global methane emissionsâ€”a potent greenhouse gas. But by removing the need for flooded fields, DSR conserves water, reduces emissions, and protects the soil. 

     ğŸš Food security â†’ With the global population expected to increase to 10 billion by 2050, it is estimated that rice production will need to increase by 35% to meet demand. Moving from conventional transplanted rice cultivation practices to a more economically viable and sustainable solution like DSR, is helping to address that need.

Shanti, a farmer in India has already seen the positive impacts of the DSR system â€“ not only for herself and her family, but also for the community of smallholder farmers in her region.  
 
At Bayer, weâ€™re here to help rice farmers like Shanti transition to more regenerative agricultural practices. We see partnerships as key to equipping farmers with agronomic advice, climate-resilient hybrids, crop protection, digital tools and more to enable farmers to produce more and restore more at the same time. 

Hand-in-hand with farmers, we aim to meet the rising demand for rice while safeguarding our planetâ€™s future. 

#FoodSecurity #DirectSeededRice #RegenAg #RegenerativeAgriculture

Food loss and waste is a global challenge occurring from the time seeds are sown to when the final products end up in the trash. It is a multifaceted problem that requires a collective effort, from farmers, factories, restaurants, governments, and all actors of the food values chain to consumers. 

Our researchers are innovating to help tackle this problem: Digital farming technologies such as soil sensors and satellites are helping to preemptively diagnose and treat various threats to crops before they take hold - helping prevent crop loss from the start. In addition, we offer farmers new varieties of seeds, along with crop protection tools, to help more crops make it off the farm.

Join us for our LinkedIn Live discussion on December 16, where we will explore how to shape climate action and rethink resilience in a world beyond 1.5 degrees. The session will feature Mojib Latif, Senior Professor at GEOMAR Helmholtz-Zentrum fÃ¼r Ozeanforschung Kiel and President of the German Association Club of Rome, along with Matthias Berninger, EVP of Public Affairs, Sustainability & Safety at Bayer.

Despite decades of global climate summits, including the recent COP29 in Baku, Azerbaijan, emissions continue to rise, and scientists warn that the Paris Agreement's 1.5-degree target is effectively out of reach. What does this mean for our approach to climate action? What changes are needed in global governance and cooperation? Do we need to reframe our understanding of climate action and how we communicate about it?

You are warmly invited to join and ask questions during the live stream! Join our event here:

Just a friendly reminder about the next round of our LinkedIn Live Talks! Tune in on December 16 at 3 p.m CET to hear Matthias Berninger, EVP Public Affairs, Sustainability & Safety at Bayer discuss with Mojib Latif, one of the most respected voices in climate research in Germany and Professor at GEOMAR, how to shape and reframe climate action in a world beyond the 1.5 degree target. The talk will cover the role of international conferences, such as the recent COP29, and the importance of international cooperation and the role of business. 

Looking beyond the challenges and focusing on solutions, the two experts will explore how to reframe the communication about climate action. A key question: How can science, business, civil society and policymakers join forces to drive meaningful change in a rapidly warming world? Join us and ask your questions! Lung cancer is a complex disease with different forms that behave differently and require tailored treatment. Broadly, it is classified into two main types: non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and small cell lung cancer (SCLC). Understanding both the type and subtype of lung cancer is crucial, as it guides treatment decisions, helps predict disease progression, and allows healthcare providers to personalise therapies for the best possible outcomes. Thrombosis is a leading cause of preventable cardiovascular events, and it can impact young people too, not just older adults. Join us in celebrating the incredible visionaries Mary E. Brunkow, Fred Ramsdell, and Shimon Sakaguchi, who have been honoured with the 2025 The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine! 

Their discovery of the critical role of regulatory T cells advanced our understanding of immune balance, paving the way for therapies targeting autoimmune diseases, cancer, and stem cell transplant complications. This has established a transformative field in medicine. The work on "suppressor T cells" essentially revived and validated a previously abandoned field through rigorous experimentation and the eventual identification of regulatory T cells. A true story of perseverance!  We firmly believe in the potential of this discovery for the future and that this science is transformative.

Let's applaud these true pioneers for their groundbreaking achievements and their immense contributions to the advancement of medical science. Their dedication and innovation deserve nothing less than a resounding standing ovation!

Millions globally and ~2 lakh people in India live with a life-limiting neurological condition called Multiple Sclerosis (MS). The disease affects their central nervous system, depriving them of their ability to perform simple everyday tasks like walking, cooking, bathing or the strength to hold a child. Their day-to-day struggle remains hidden and performing everyday tasks can feel like scaling an invisible mountain. 

#RochePharmaIndia in collaboration with the Multiple Sclerosis Society of India (MSSI) presents #WalkInMyShoes - a public health awareness initiative to highlight the often invisible struggles of individuals living with this life-limiting neurological condition. It reflects our deep commitment to raising awareness, breaking down stigma, and advocating for those whose struggles often go unheard and unseen. 

The #WalkInMyShoes simulation zones will re-create a sensory experience of four of the most commonly occurring MS symptoms - loss of balance, motor impairment, blurry vision and loss of sensitivity to spark conversations, build a sense of community and bring to the forefront the everyday challenges that MS patients face. 

We invite you to walk with us and experience #EmpathyInAction at the following locations:
Bangalore: ğŸ“ Brookfield Ecospace, Bellandur (Near 1C) ğŸ“† 20 to 22 August
Mumbai: ğŸ“ Phoenix MarketCity, Kurla (Atrium 5, LG floor) ğŸ“† 22 to 24 August

You can also show your support by sharing a story, starting a conversation using #WalkInMyShoes and help us elevate the voices of those navigating life with MS â€” often quietly, but always courageously. For more information, log on to www.walkinmyshoes.in

Roche Diagnostics is pleased to share this exciting news!! 

We're proud to announce our second regulatory clearance leveraging real-world data (RWD).

RWD refers to data collected outside of traditional randomized controlled trials, such as data from electronic health records, claims and billing data, product and disease registries, and patient-generated data. During the pandemic, we partnered with Columbia University Irving Medical Center to collect RWD that demonstrated the clinical performance of a COVID-19 serology assay in real-world settings.

These RWD, coupled with clinical study data, led to the successful transition from FDA Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) to the 510k clearance. This accomplishment highlights the value of RWD in shaping regulatory decisions and providing clinicians with reliable diagnostic tools.

We're grateful to all our collaborators at the Medical Device Innovation Consortium (MDIC) Open Hand Initiative, which enabled us to gain timely feedback, FDA engagement throughout the years, and Columbia University Irving Medical Center, for their dedication to advancing patient care through innovation and data-driven insights. 

#RocheDiagnostics #RealWorldData #RegulatoryApproval #COVID19 #Diagnostics #HealthcareInnovation

ğŸ” Accurate diagnosis of Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) remains a global challenge, with chest pain being one of the most frequent reasons for emergency department admissions. 

Roche's new CE-marked Chest Pain Triage algorithm aims to alleviate this burden by providing precise triage options for suspected NSTEMI patients.

This algorithm leverages cardiac troponin results to deliver reliable recommendations based on the 0/1, 0/2, or 0/3 accelerated diagnostic protocols established by the European Society of Cardiology. Seamlessly integrated into the electronic patient record, it enables data pre-population and enhances documentation efficiency, facilitating optimal patient management.

Can digital health solutions address misdiagnoses and medical errors?

In cardiology and emergency medicine, the stakes around these errors are very high, due to the life-threatening nature of conditions treated in these specialties.

In the latest Cardio Insights episode hosted by Mathieu Chaffard, Prof. Wolf Hautz lifts the veil on the complexity of medical decisions in these specialties, and why digital solutions need to go beyond applications specific to one condition and provide more agnostic guidance to have an impact in the field. 

His thesis encourages the convergence of cognitive psychology and digital innovation, as a key to developing future solutions for the benefit of patients and healthcare professionals.

Cardio Insights is a podcast produced by Roche, exploring how digital solutions are transforming cardiovascular and emergency medicine!

Tune in to this podcast today on Spotify, Apple Podcasts, and YouTube: https://spkl.io/6043fs4at

#CardioInsights #Cardiology #EmergencyMedicine #DigitalHealth

Exciting times as we proudly announce our first #FDA clearance achieved through the innovative use of Real World Data (RWD). This milestone isnâ€™t just a regulatory winâ€”itâ€™s a game changer in how we advance diagnostic submissions and enhance patient care.

RWD relating to patient health status and/or the delivery of health care routinely collected from sources like electronic health records, insurance claims, and patient registries, offering us a true reflection of real-world patient care practices. A shining example of this approach is our collaboration with IQVIA and the National Football League (NFL) COVID-19 Surveillance Program. By leveraging comprehensive RT-PCR testing data from 32 NFL teams during the height of the pandemic in 2020, we gained invaluable insights into the performance of PCR COVID-19 testing in asymptomatic individuals, leading to claim expansion in this population.

Harnessing RWD enables us to accelerate the development and approval of #diagnostics, ultimately helping pave the way for faster, more personalized care. As we continue to partner with regulatory bodies like the FDA, we are excited to shape the future of healthcare and make a lasting positive impact on patient outcomes.

#MedTech #Biotechnology #RegulatoryAffairs

How is digital health changing cardiovascular and emergency medicine?

In the age of digitalization and artificial intelligence, healthcare systems must adapt to cope with the pressure imposed by chronic diseases and increasingly limited available resources.

Did you know that Novartis has the largest pipeline for Neglected Tropical Diseases in the sector, according to the Access to Medicine Index?
 
We're working to deliver breakthrough innovations for people living with conditions like Chagas disease, a parasitic infection that affects millions of people around the world. It is often transmitted through the bite of the so-called "kissing bug" and can lead to heart disease.
 
Together with our partners, we are working to turn the tide on Chagas disease by strengthening community health systems in remote areas, advancing research for new potential treatments, and trialling drug candidates to treat Chagas heart disease.

At #WEF25, our CEO Vas Narasimhan joined international health leaders to discuss how strengthening health systems and expanding access to innovation can transform healthcare globally.

Wildfires pose a costly threat, but proactive land management can make a real difference! Land managers partner with communities to develop Integrated Vegetation Management (IVM) plans that use selective herbicide products, key tools for vegetation thinning, prescribed burns, and fuel breaks, to alter fire behavior. Our goal is to help communities proactively mitigate fire risk and to support faster recovery. Want to learn more? Visit https://bit.ly/4lsauVH #KeepGrowing

BASF is targeting the Frankfurt stock exchange as the listing location for its Agricultural Solutions business. The planned initial public offering (IPO) of Agricultural Solutions as a European company (Societas Europaea, SE) represents a major milestone in BASFâ€™s â€œWinning Waysâ€ strategy. It will establish the standalone business as an independent, pure-play agricultural company with global reach, robust growth prospects and strong cash flow generation. BASF will remain the majority shareholder and will continue to benefit from the companyâ€™s growth and success, while implementing market customary corporate governance.

As of May 1, 2026, a new Management Board will lead Agricultural Solutions through its transition to an independent, publicly listed company. It will comprise four members:

- Livio Tedeschi, President, BASF Agricultural Solutions, will assume overall responsibility as the Head of the Management Board. He will also become member of the Board of Executive Directors of BASF SE with responsibility for the Agricultural Solutions segment effective May 1, 2026, as previously announced.

-Â Sascha Bibert will join BASF Agricultural Solutions from Vallourec SA and, as Member of the Management Board, be in charge of Finance.

-Â Maximilian Becker, Senior Vice President Vegetable Seeds, BASF Agricultural Solutions, will, as Member of the Management Board, be in charge of Business.

-Â Melanie Bausen-Wiens, Senior Vice President Regulatory, 
 Stewardship & Public Affairs, BASF Agricultural Solutions, will, as Member of the Management Board, be in charge of Technology.

The Quarterly Statement Q3 2025 of BASF group has been published: In a demanding environment, BASF achieves earnings slightly above market expectations and only slightly below Q3 2024.
Positive volume development was outweighed by negative currency effects and lower prices, resulting in sales declining 3% compared with the prior-year quarter. At â‚¬1.5 billion, BASF Groupâ€™s EBITDA before special items, including the discontinued coatings business, was down slightly by â‚¬78 million compared with the same quarter of the previous year.
In view of cash proceeds already received and further proceeds expected, particularly from portfolio measures, BASF will start a share buyback program, as already announced yesterday. The program, which has a volume of up to â‚¬1.5 billion, is scheduled to start in November 2025 and be concluded by the end of June 2026. It is part of the share buyback announced at the Capital Markets Day in September 2024, with a total volume of â‚¬4 billion until the end of 2028. These share buybacks were originally scheduled to begin by 2027 at the latest. Part of them will now be brought forward.

The Supervisory Board of BASF SE today appointed Dr. Mary Kurian (48) and Dr. Livio Tedeschi (54) as members of the Board of Executive Directors effective May 1, 2026. At the same time, Michael Heinz (61) will retire as planned.

Mary Kurian was born in India. After obtaining a PhD in Materials Science in 2004, she held various leadership positions at Air Products in the United States and joined BASF in the United States in the year 2020. Since 2023, she has been heading BASFâ€™s Care Chemicals division located in Ludwigshafen.

Livio Tedeschi will assume responsibility for the Agricultural Solutions segment. The native Italian has been leading the Agricultural Solutions division, located in Limburgerhof, Germany, since 2022. He joined BASF after completing a PhD in Organic Chemistry in 2003 and had various leadership positions with a focus on crop protection since that time. Regarding the planned partial IPO of the Agricultural Solutions division, he will assume responsibility for this segment with a new Board Ressort and continue to lead the business.

Nina Schwab-Hautzinger, Head of Corporate Communications & Government Relations, will leave BASF effective January 31, 2026, to take on a new professional opportunity. The company will announce the successor in due course.

Markus Kamieth, Chairman of the Board of Executive Directors of BASFÂ SE, said: â€œDuring her five years at BASF, Nina Schwab-Hautzinger has successfully advanced and modernized our corporate communications. She has represented BASFâ€™s values both internally and externally with impact, and together with her team has further strengthened the companyâ€™s reputation. She demonstrated strong leadership during the challenging period of the energy crisis. Communication was also a key success factor during the CEO transition and the launch of our corporate â€˜Winning Waysâ€™ strategy. I truly enjoyed working with her and regret that she will be leaving BASF. I wish her all the best for her next role.â€

Nina Schwab-Hautzinger has led BASFâ€™s Corporate Communications & Government Relations unit since 2020. Prior to that, she held various international leadership positions at healthcare company Roche in Switzerland and Germany, as well as at a strategic communications consultancy in Singapore. She studied at the universities of Mannheim and Waterloo, Canada, and earned her doctorate from the University of Zurich.

BASF and funds managed by global investment firm Carlyle (NASDAQ: CG), in partnership with Qatar Investment Authority (QIA), have entered into a binding agreement relating to BASFâ€™s automotive OEM coatings, automotive refinish coatings, and surface treatment businesses (â€œBASF Coatingsâ€).



The enterprise value of the transaction amounts to â‚¬7.7 billion. Subject to customary regulatory approvals, the transaction is expected to close in Q2 2026. This transaction, together with the already closed divestiture of the decorative paints business, value BASFâ€™s entire Coatings division at an enterprise value of â‚¬8.7 billion and an implied 2024 EV/EBITDA multiple before special items of approx. 13x. This represents a significant step in unlocking the value of BASFâ€™s standalone businesses, as the company swiftly executes its Winning Ways strategy. BASF will also reinvest in the coatings business holding a 40% equity stake and will receive pre-tax cash proceeds of approx. â‚¬5.8 billion at closing of the transaction.



Working closely alongside management, Carlyle will support the future growth of the business through investing in its commercial capabilities, innovation pipeline, and organizational structure to enhance customer focus. Carlyle will leverage its strong track record and extensive experience in successful carve-outs of industrial and chemical assets, following previous investments in Axalta, Atotech, and Nouryon.



More in our joint press release: https://lnkd.in/en__JhTE

Congratulations to Susumu Kitagawa, Richard Robson, and Omar M. Yaghi for receiving the 2025 #NobelPrize in #Chemistry for their pioneering work on metalâ€“organic frameworks (#MOFs).

The scientists developed a new kind of molecular structure that combines metals and organic molecules. The metals act as nodes, linked by organic molecules containing carbon, forming large, empty spaces inside the frameworks through which gases and other materials can flow.

#MOFs can be used to harvest water from desert air, capture carbon dioxide, store toxic gases, or catalyze chemical reactionsâ€”therefore revolutionizing #science and #industry.

Did you know? Omar Yaghi is co-founder of the California Research Alliance (CARA) by BASF.

#BASF is also proud to be the first company to produce MOFs for COâ‚‚ capture on an industrial scale, offering customized solutions for a wide range of industries and applications worldwide.

#Nobel Prize #2025 # BASF #Innovation #Science

Weâ€™re proud to share the new â€œOECD Best Practice Guide on Chemical Data Sharing Between Companiesâ€.
BASF welcomed and proactively helped draft this guidance together with industry peers and stakeholders. It advances practical, fair and transparent dataâ€‘sharingâ€”essential to protect human health and the environment, avoid duplicate studies (including animal testing), and enable consistent regulatory submissions worldwide.
Aligned with the Internation Council of Chemical Associationsâ€™ (ICCAâ€™s) ambition for transparency under the new political â€œGlobal Framework on Chemicalsâ€, the guide supports broader access to reliable safety data and promotes cross-fertilization of regulatory practice across regions. Greater transparency will help regulators, industry and civil society make betterâ€‘informed decisions, reduce unnecessary testing, and foster trust among stakeholders.
As part of ICCA, BASF members played an active role in developing the guide in cooperation with associations, companies and other interested parties. This collaborative effort demonstrates the value of multiâ€‘stakeholder engagement to tackle practical challengesâ€”finding who owns data, clarifying rights to use or refer to studies, and agreeing fair compensation mechanisms.
Read the OECD guide and join the conversation on how we can work together to make chemical safety information more accessible, reliable and useful worldwide: https://lnkd.in/eN3aeyEP

At BASF, we adhere to our climate protection targets and promote a fundamental understanding of sustainable development. This is our core message at New York Climate Week, where leaders in sustainability from around the world are gathering to discuss the most challenging sustainability topics.
While sustainability is central to our strategy, we also acknowledge that our customers are taking different paths in their sustainability transformations. Priorities and pace vary by region and by industry. We cannot determine the pace alone: everyone is called upon to act â€” markets, investors, policymakers, civil society, and end consumers. New life for old batteries - directly in Schwarzheide. Our plant for the production of Black Mass was successfully put into operation. The state-of-the-art plant is one of the largest commercial facilities of its kind in Europe. 15,000 tons of discarded lithium-ion batteries and production waste can be processed here every year.

Battery recycling is a key factor in achieving independence from primary raw material sources and strengthening the circular economy. The production of Black Mass is an important step in the battery recycling process because it is rich in lithium, nickel, cobalt and manganese.

Today, we published our audited annual report for the business year 2024. It contains all key financial figures and comprehensively documents BASFâ€™s environmental, social and governance performance. It shows how the company creates value for its stakeholders and how sustainability contributes to BASFâ€™s long-term success.
For the first time, the sustainability part of the report was voluntarily prepared in accordance with the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS). BASF has identified the following topics as material and reports fully aligned with the respective standards: Environmental (Climate Change; Pollution Prevention; Water; Biodiversity and Ecosystems; Resource Use and Circular Economy), Social (Own Workforce; Workers in the Value Chain; Affected Communities) and Governance (Business Conduct). For each topic, the BASF Report discloses identified impacts, risks and opportunities and shows how BASF integrates material environmental, social and governance aspects in its strategy, core steering processes and management systems.

#BASFreport #BASF #ESRS

Attributed biogenic carbon is a vital componentÂ in many chemicals and derived products. Our goal is to provide it sustainably, ensuring the long-term success of the green transformation of the chemical industry. 

At BASF, we are committed to driving thought leadership in the bioeconomy space. Our recently released Perspective Chapter, titled "The Growing Importance of Bio-Attributed Products in Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions," co-authored by esteemed sustainability thought leaders Dr. Ivana KrkljuÅ¡, Christian Krueger and Peter Saling, serves as a significant contribution to this discourse. It underscores BASF's commitment to sourcing renewable feedstocks, to reduce the uptake of fossil resources and to thereby consequently mitigate the greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions caused by purchased feedstocks. This book chapter is the first-of-its-kind, emphasizing the significance of bio-attributed products and its contribution to the reduction ofÂ ScopeÂ 3 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. 

BASF is offering a range of bio-derived (bio-based and bio-attributed) products to its customers. Bio-based products are derived from renewable materials such as vegetable oils, fats, grains, sugar, and wood, and used for products supplied to cosmetics industry, for pharmaceuticals, etc. Our range of bio-attributed products allows the attribution of the renewable feedstock via a mass balance approach to the products where our customers are willing to pay the premium that is needed. Using interlinked production facilities and highly optimized processes ensures that all materials are used in the most (cost) efficient way whilst maintaining product quality and performance. We work together with recognized sustainability certification systems such as ISCC PLUS or REDcert2 to ensure transparency and accountability.  

Key concepts discussed in the book chapter:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Insights on the role of bio-attributed products and their importance in greenhouse gas emissions reduction. Â 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â The concept of Mass Balance Chain of Custody (MB CoC) and its attribution principles easily explained. 
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â The way of combining the MB CoC for material and energy tracking in supply chains and the Life Cycle Assessment (LCA)methodology.
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Driving Change via expansion of bio-attributed products, the concept that allows to substitute large quantities of fossil raw materials and continuously increase the shares of renewable raw materials. 

We invite you to explore this important work and consider benefits of bio-attributed products in meeting self-defined GHG emission targets and regulatory-imposed sustainability targets.

Read the chapter now: https://lnkd.in/eXvjVNin 
Our chapter is distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution License (https://lnkd.in/evRSGrcG), allowing for unrestricted use and distribution with proper citation.
#MassBalance #LifeCycle #Sustainability #Bioeconomy #CircularEconomy #TfS

At BASF, we're not just reducing carbon emissions, we're also redefining resource consumption. By harnessing organic carbon from renewable materials, we are driving the transition away from fossil resources. Our transformation centers on defossilization instead of decarbonization alone, which often involves reducing carbon emissions without addressing the source of the carbon itself. By defossilizing, we can fundamentally change the raw materials used in our production, ensuring a more sustainable and circular economy.
Our newly established BASF Renewable Carbon (BReC) unit is at the forefront of this transformation, exploring diverse renewable feedstocks and collaborating with suppliers and partners to redefine value chains.
In our kickoff article, we delve into the transformative power of renewable carbon and its role in enabling the green transformation â€“ of our customers and of BASF. Discover how diverse organic sources can serve as alternative raw materials, facilitating the production of biobased and biomass-balanced products enabling low and Zero product carbon footprints - without compromising on quality or performance. 
But thatâ€™s just the beginning! Stay tuned for other focus topics on:
- Â Â The Growing Importance of Bio-Attributed Products in Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions highlighted by a book chapter co-authored by BASF experts
- Biomass balanced products and their role for the green transformation of our customers
- How sustainable oils and fats are redefining feedstocks for the chemical industry
- The bioeconomy as key pillar for industrial net zero production in the European Union
Join us on our Renewable Carbon journey and explore how we can shape the transformation of the chemical industry!
#RenewableCarbon #GreenTransformation #CircularEconomy #NetZero #Bioeconomy #BASF #InnovativeSolutions #BiomassBalanced #LowPCF #ZeroPCF

In November 1938, he was arrested in Mannheim the day after the "Reichspogromnacht" and deported to the Dachau concentration camp. At the request of I.G. Farben, Reg. Architect Max Falkenberg was released after a few weeks. However, the loyal Aniliner was not allowed to return to his job. Like other Jewish or so-called Jewish employees from 1938 onwards, he had to accept his dismissal.
The entire documented story of Max Falkenberg is told by BASF as part of the remembrance project â€œTracing Fates.â€ On the occasion of the 80th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, BASF aims to contribute to the commemoration of the victims of National Socialism.

In 2025, we commemorate the 80th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz and the end of World War II. Through a remembrance project, BASF traces the fates of eight people, mostly of Jewish descent, who were employed at the I.G. Farben plants in Ludwigshafen and Oppau and became victims of Nazi persecution. It is a search for traces in fragmentary records.
With the project â€œTracing Fates,â€ as fragmentary as the reconstructions may be, we also aim to remember all those who suffered immeasurable pain and loss between 1933 and 1945. Long before the regime systematically murdered persecuted groups, it gradually stripped them of their rights. It destroyed their social, economic, and cultural existence.
Read more at https://lnkd.in/eu8QNrUz
#HolocaustRemembranceDay #DayOfRemembrance

Can artificial intelligence discriminate?
Robin Pocornie made this experience with a facial recognition software at her university. It was unable to recognize students with darker skin tones. As a result, she faced issues during her exams, unlike her white peers.
Since then, she has been advocating for fair and just AI decision-making and calling for greater transparency in algorithmic decision
systems. Pocornie suggests a local data management, conducting bias audits, and shifting the focus from purely technological metrics to equity-centred metrics.
The whole story is available in our #CreatingChemistry storyhub: https://lnkd.in/eu67Zb7H
#ArtificalIntelligence #Discrimination #Transparency #FacialRecognitionSoftware

BASF officially opened its new Catalyst Development and Solids Processing Center in Ludwigshafen, Germany. This research facility will serve as a hub for pilot-scale synthesis of chemical catalysts, enabling BASF to offer its global customers faster access to innovative technologies. This pilot plant will also be of central importance for the development of new solids processing technologies.

Catalysts play a key role in industrial chemistry. More than 80 percent of all chemical products come into contact with a catalyst at least once during their production. Catalysts reduce the energy demand and the amount of undesired by-products. Thereby, they minimize raw material consumption and shrink the carbon footprint of products. Catalysts are used in many areas, including the chemical and petrochemical industries, as well as in innovative processes
essential for the green transformation. BASF not only develops catalyst and process technologies for its customers worldwide, it also uses them in its own manufacturing plants.

#researchanddevelopment #winningways #basfteam #greentransformation #researchcenter #science #chemistry

Sustainable oil supply: How BASF's Partnership with INOCAS Drives Renewable Feedstock
We are advancing our sustainability portfolio by partnering with Innovative Oil and Carbon Solutions (INOCAS) to develop the cultivation of MacaÃºba, a native tree in Brazil, and to process its pulp and kernel oil. The long-term Supplier Finance Agreement between BASF and INOCAS includes an offtake agreement for a reliable and sustainable supply of MacaÃºba Kernel Oil (MKO) and MacaÃºba Pulp Oil (MPO). The partnership will enable us to further expand our renewable-based portfolio. "MacaÃºba", a native Brazilian tree (Acrocomia aculeata), is known for its extensive dispersion across Brazil and its resilience in dry conditions and degraded soil. 
Since 2015, INOCAS has developed, implemented and refined an innovative model to cultivate MacaÃºba trees on degraded pastureland, and to improve soil quality and productivity. Based on its strong intellectual property and experience, INOCAS aims to plant at least 50,000 hectares of MacaÃºba in partnership with smallholder farmers by 2030. This system supports regenerative agriculture by combining forestry and livestock farming without an additional land use change. It has positive impacts on soil quality, erosion control and biodiversity. Agricultural partnerships with smallholder farmers aim at improving livelihoods for their families. 
The partnership also includes financing of INOCASâ€™ plans to develop the MacaÃºba oil production in Brazil on an industrial scale. The project will generate significant benefits in environmental, social, and economic terms. These efforts align seamlessly with BASFâ€™s commitment to sustainability and reinforce our dedication to reduce the consumption of fossil-based feedstock and replace it with alternative raw materials. As demand for sustainable products continues to grow, our ability to integrate MKO and MPO into our value chains is another essential stepstone for supporting our customers' green transformations.
Learn more about this exciting project by following the link to our press release: https://lnkd.in/eNhN2De2

It is our honor to be a part of the history of the Indiana State Fairgrounds. With the introduction of the newly named Corteva Coliseum, we're connecting to our deep Hoosier roots and celebrating a remarkable institution. Many of us local to Indiana have fond memories from past fairs. That's why we asked attendees of the #CortevaColiseum ribbon cutting to share their favorite memories in celebration of this next chapter.

The earth moved. Buildings shook. On March 28, a 7.7-7.9 magnitude earthquake struck Myanmar, the most powerful since 1912 and the second deadliest since the 1930s. The impact was so large that neighboring countries China, Thailand, and even distant Vietnam received structural damage. For many residents, this was their first time encountering a natural disaster on this scale.

To aid these communities where we operate, Corteva Asia Pacific swiftly mobilized to support relief efforts. The Thailand team collaborated with Rise Against Hunger, the Rotary Club of Shwe Bangkok, and Disaster Aid Thailand to organize a dedicated team of 70 Corteva employees and 50 Rotarians to pack 100,000 meals for those in need.

This impactful initiative, completed on April 23, saw our teams contribute a combined 600 volunteer hours towards relief efforts. We commend the Thailand team and all those involved for living our Corteva values - their swift action and generous contributions during this critical time as well as powerful display of teamwork and compassion have made a huge difference for the affected communities.

In moments like these, we are reminded of our shared humanity and the importance of coming together. Reflecting on the strength that our teams and partners showed, we are inspired to continue making a positive impact in the world that goes beyond business transactions and borders.

Thanks to our world-class R&D program, we continue to uphold our sustainable innovation goal, that 100% of newly-developed solutions in our pipeline meet our sustainability criteria. Swipe for a few impactful ways we're pushing ourÂ efforts forward. #KeepGrowing

We are supporting biodiversity where we live and work. Our impact comes from our products, technology-driven productivity, partnerships with like-minded organizations and operational improvements. Read about our impact hereÂ https://lnkd.in/eraxF8dx #KeepGrowing

We are proud to announce that Pfizer has reached a definitive agreement to acquire Metsera, a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company. This acquisition will enhance our Internal Medicine portfolio and help us address the significant unmet needs in obesity and cardiometabolic disease.

Obesity is a major global health challenge, contributing to chronic diseases, shortened lifespans, and rising healthcare costs. While GLP-1 medications have made strides, there is still a significant unmet need among patients with obesity and the more than 200 associated health conditions.

Metsera brings a portfolio of promising therapeutic candidates, including clinical-stage programs investigating potential best-in-class injectables. By applying Pfizer's deep cardiometabolic experience, manufacturing capabilities, and clinical expertise to the advancement of Metseraâ€™s portfolio, we aim to reshape the treatment landscape with more effective, better-tolerated, and convenient medicines.

We expect to close this deal in the fourth quarter, subject to satisfaction of customary closing conditions, receipt of regulatory approvals and Metseraâ€™s shareholders' approval.

Learn more about todayâ€™s announcement: https://lnkd.in/g3FP7ra3

The 'Underserved Within' Phenomenon - An Important Perspective on Vaccination Disparities
Â 
Despite advancements in healthcare, vaccination rates in Europe are still not meeting targets. This problem is especially bad in marginalized communities like the traveling population and new immigrants.
Â 
Another important group that is often overlooked are people from mixed economic backgrounds within the same communities. These "underserved within" face complex barriers to getting vaccinated. This includes issues with access, not trusting information sources, and economic differences.
Â 
To address these complex differences, we need tailored, grassroots efforts to understand individual perspectives and situations. Ensuring equitable access to healthcare, regardless of socioeconomic status, is crucial.
Â

In collaboration with Rise Against Hunger and Global Giving, Corteva Vietnam has packaged 50,000 nutritious meals for distribution. Nguyen Yen, Fruit and Vegetable Manager for Vietnam, grew up in a peaceful village in An Giang province, located in the Mekong Delta. â€œThroughout Vietnam, women in agriculture play diverse roles. I have learned from their experiences, and it has been an empowering and positive journey. â€œMy advice to those considering a career in agriculture: Be a farmer, think like farmer, think agriculture. Never stop solving their pain points by bringing high-quality products and improving technology so that farmers like my parents can protect their farms every day.â€

Ms. Poonam, a 32-year-old from a remote village in India, dreamt of making a difference. 

Completing her middle school education, she went on to juggle roles as a homemaker and owner of a stitching shop. Her path changed in 2022 when she joined a Farmer Producer Organization (FPO). The FPO enabled women with training in DSR farming, Mahua (commonly known as butter tree) fruits and flowers processing & pea cultivation.

Engaging in extensive outreach, she visited surrounding villages, conducted meetings and created awareness among local farmers on the benefits of joining the FPO. Her efforts resulted in the successful integration and empowerment of over 600 female farmers, fostering a sense of community and teamwork. 

As her influence grew, Poonam actively engaged with local authorities, including the district CEO and District Magistrate. Her dedication made her a recognized advocate for women's empowerment and agriculture within the district.

This Kisan Diwas or National Farmer's Day, we celebrate the unwavering spirit of India's farmers - pioneers of innovation, champions of sustainability, and guardians of our food security.

As a major agricultural producer, India is embracing sustainability and innovation, blending traditional practices like crop rotation with modern techniques for efficiency.  Women in farming are becoming community leaders, advocating for sustainability, empowerment, and collaboration, improving food security and resilience.  Researchers are developing solutions for India's diverse climates, using biotechnology for high-yield, pest-resistant crops and regenerative practices for soil health.  Food entrepreneurship is thriving with farm-to-table projects and agri-tech startups. Young innovators connect farmers directly with consumers, enhancing profits and produce quality.  

Indian farmers are balancing tradition with modernity, ensuring agriculture adapts to the needs of the modern world while honoring heritage, signifying a definable phase that will impact the food future.

#KisanDiwas #FutureOfFarming #NationalFarmersDay

Sustainability is particularly critical in the agriculture sector, as it directly impacts food security, environmental health, and the livelihoods of billions of people. We remain dedicated to this with 100% of our products designed to be sustainable. Our efforts have been honoured with recognition of Salibro, a nematicide, at FICCI Sustainable Agriculture Summit and Awards 2024 in India, marking the fourth consecutive year of this recognition. It secured the second place in the Farmer Income Enhancement category. 

Salibro, effectively controls harmful nematodes while significantly enhancing soil microflora and fauna. This dual strategy not only improves soil health but also increases crop yields by 10-30% and farmer incomes by 10-15%. Salibro is more than just a product, it is an integral component of our vision for the future of agriculture, where every farmer can acknowledge and utilize the inherent value of #soilhealth for the prosperity of their land and livelihoods.

Through innovation and farmer empowerment we are building a foundation for a greener and more resilient tomorrow. 

#StartAtTheRoots #FutureOfFarming

Women in India hold a vital position within the agricultural sector, and their contributions extend beyond farming and labor; they are increasingly engaging in research and emerging as entrepreneurs. While there are numerous compelling stories from every village, town, and district, here's one exemplary woman whose determination led to significant transformation. 

Rani Devi from Pandpa village in Bihar, married at a young age. Constrained by domestic responsibilities, her aspirations were hindered by societal resistance. Nevertheless, she seized the opportunity to join us and Professional Assistance for Development Action (PRADAN) as a Community Resource Person (CRP), where she trained farmers in the Direct Sowing of Rice (DSR). With this knowledge and backing, Rani cultivated DSR on 0.6 acres, achieving an impressive yield of 14.5 quintals, significantly surpassing traditional methods. 

This accomplishment provided her with additional income and altered her family's perception. Her husband began to share household responsibilities and acknowledged her contributions. Presently, Rani is a passionate advocate for DSR and women's empowerment, guiding more than 100 farmers across districts. We take great pride in Rani and wholeheartedly support her ongoing journey. 

#2MillionWomen #SheThrives #Corteva #Agriculture #InItForFarmers

Saroj Devi, a millet farmer from Bharatpur, was married at the age of 18. While she actively assisted her husband in farming, she aspired to increase her family's income to cover her daughter's coaching fees and her son's college education. To pursue this goal, she participated in our women farmer training program. 

During this program, she learned to enhance her farming practices and incorporate hybrid millet, which offers better resistance to drought, pests, and diseases. She chose to cultivate hybrid millet on 20 acres of her 40-acre land. As a result, Saroj significantly reduced her pesticide and fertilizer costs, improved the quality of her millet, achieved higher market prices, increased her crop yield, and augmented her family income. 

Today, she supports her family and promotes hybrid millet farming, highlighting its advantages, such as higher yields, cost savings, and financial security, while encouraging fellow farmers to adopt these practices.

#SheThrives #Corteva #Agriculture #InItForFarmers
