Cancer diagnoses are projected to reach 35 million by 2050. 

Yet each case is unique, depending on where the tumor originates, its genetic characteristics, the stage at diagnosis, and importantly, the characteristics of each individual person affected. With this, treatments must become more precise. Antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs)â€”designed to deliver cancer medicines directly to tumorsâ€”have the potential to transform cancer treatment.

Behind every breakthrough in cancer therapy are dedicated scientists, researchers, and clinicians working tirelessly to change the trajectory of this disease. On this World Cancer Research Day, we thank Jan Anderl, Global Head of ADC Technologies at Merck Healthcare, his team, clinical researchers, and our many biopharma partners worldwide who help create a world where more cancer patients can become cancer survivors. 

#WorldCancerResearchDay

Which elements from the periodic table can make our electronics smarter by enhancing their speed and performance? 

High-k gate oxides, like hafnium, are the answer! These materials have been effectively used for some time in the dielectric layers of transistors, allowing for high switching speeds with slightly thicker films. This means less leakage and lower power consumption in our logic circuits.

The result? Improved performance, reduced energy waste, and lower operating costsâ€”all while being kinder to the environment!

Liquid crystals but not as you know it. 

You've likely heard of liquid crystal display televisions, tablets and smartphones but did you know how beautiful they can be? Under the microscope liquid crystal mixtures, like these pictured, look different depending on temperature, applied electrical voltage, and if they have been combined with other substances.

More precisely, to power chip technology that you can find in every smartphone, tablet and TV! We use two-thirds of the non-radioactive elements in our semiconductor products and research and development.

This is a Schistosoma parasitic flatworm. 

Often overlooked, it silently transmits a disease that currently affects more than 250 million people mainly living in Africa. The minuscule larvae penetrate human skin of people in infected waters, enter the blood vessels and attack internal organs.

Schistosomiasis, also known as bilharzia, named after its discoverer Theodor Bilharz, is the second most dangerous parasitic disease after malaria, and one of the twenty-one neglected tropical diseases. 

Through our efforts, we are working to combat this disease and together with partners, we aim to eliminate it as a public health problem by 2030.

#WorldNTDDay #UniteActEliminate #BeatNTDs 
World Health Organization Uniting to Combat Neglected Tropical Diseases

Our New CSR Initiative in India: Maternal Vaccination Awareness & Sensitization Program

The program aims to enhance maternal vaccination awareness in communities by building healthcare workers' capacity to address vaccine hesitancy and strengthen community vaccine confidence. 

Our CSR partner BharatCares recently conducted the pilot launch in Kolkata in collaboration with the Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC). The event featured 70+ Front Line Workers who will drive this initiative along with distinguished guests including Dr. Tapan Kumar Mukherjee (Honorary Health Advisor) and Dr. Ronita Sengupta (Chief Municipal Health Officer). Leaders from Sanofi in India including Vinifer Gandhi, Nitya Padmanabhan and Dr. Kavita Chaudhari (She/Her), attended the event virtually. As the next stage, the initiative will also be launched in Pune.

In India, approximately 30 million women experience pregnancy and 27 million have live births annually*. While maternal immunization can protect both mothers and babies from vaccine-preventable diseases, a significant awareness gap exists, especially in rural and lower socio-economic communities. Vaccine hesitancy may also be due to low perceived risk of vaccine-preventable diseases, along with misconceptions and myths about vaccination.

Through initiatives like the Maternal Vaccination Awareness & Sensitization Program, we're taking on some of the world's most pressing challenges to improve health outcomes for vulnerable communities. When we empower healthcare workers and educate communities, we create lasting change - one mother, one baby, one family at a time.

*Reference: http://spkl.io/6049AZd3t.

Alka used to fall sick very often as a child. She was not growing well and had difficulty in walking. All common diagnoses were ruled out through multiple tests and yet a final diagnosis seemed elusive. After a particularly severe bout, she was referred for genetic testing, which led to the diagnosis of Gaucher disease.
 
Gaucher is a rare genetic disorder due to absence of an important enzyme that causes enlargement of the spleen or liver, bone abnormalities and blood disorders. It is estimated to affect more than 20,000 kids like Alka in India.
 
Timely diagnosis and taking the right Enzyme Replacement Therapy under the supervision of doctors helps in addressing many health issues related to Gaucher disease. There are success stories of Alka and others living with Gaucher who are happily married, have children, pursue their passion and lead a near-normal life, thanks to their early diagnosis and access to treatment. 
 
Although rare diseases are individually uncommon, 7,000+ identified rare diseases collectively affect 300 million people worldwide*. People with rare diseases are not just statistics - they are individuals with hopes, dreams, and potential.
 
This International Gaucher Day, let our collective Roar for Rare become louder. Start one conversation today and join us in our endeavour to spread awareness on Gaucher disease. After all, #EveryLifeIsPrecious  
 
Watch this video to learn Alkaâ€™s inspirational story. To know more about Gaucher and other rare diseases, visit us at http://spkl.io/6044AVNkw
 
#RareDiseases #InternationalGaucherMonth #GaucherDisease #SanofiIndia

Only 5% of the 10,000+ known rare diseases have approved treatments. 

Our R&D strategy is built to tackle this challenge from two fronts: 

Molecularly Defined Disorders: Targeting the genetic root of disease with enzyme replacement therapies in metabolic diseases, innovations in hemophilia, and exploring next-generation gene therapies. 

Immune-Driven Mechanisms: Harnessing immunoscience to target harmful inflammation and pursue potentially restorative approaches. 

In our latest article, Global Head of Rare Diseases Research, Pablo Sardi, shares how we aim to bring transformational therapies to patients that are too often overlooked: http://spkl.io/6041AraQU

Organ Donation: Bridging the Gap Between Need and Hope

~ 2 lakh patients are diagnosed with End Stage Kidney Disease every year in India. Yet, only ~5% of patients receive a kidney transplant*. This critical gap between the need for organs and willingness of donors in India can be narrowed by addressing common myths that prevent potential donors from coming forward.

Take a moment to ask yourself - what stops you from signing up your organs for donation or donating to your loved ones in need? In fact, ~90% of kidney transplants are made possible through living and related donors from immediate family*.

As we commemorate World Organ Donation Day today, let's remember that sharing an organ is like sharing the gift of life. Consider pledging your organs today. Learn more about kidney donation: http://spkl.io/6049AKN83

#SanofiIndia #SharingLife #WorldOrganDonationDay #OrganDonation
medha mahadik Anjana Viswanathan Rucha Punse Dr. Milan Choksey Vinifer Gandhi 

*Sources:
1.	Kher V et al. Kidney Transplantation in India-Past, Present and Future. Indian J Nephrol. doi: 10.25259/IJN_540_2024
2.	NOTTO. Data for organ donation and transplantation. 2013-2023.

Detecting a #MultipleSclerosis diagnosis can be a long, challenging journey. Innovative research in MS is critical for finding solutions to identify MS symptoms early.  

Delayed MS diagnoses can lead to unseen disability progression â€“ known as smoldering neuroinflammation. Despite being on treatment, disability can continue to progress for some people living with MS. 

Greater understanding of these different aspects of disability progression is needed so people with MS can live for the moment, not for the disease.

Despite current therapies, many people living with #CIDP continue to struggle with loss of motor function, sensation, weakness, and pain. 

For people living with CIDP, a third do not respond to treatment. Among responders, 70% experience only partial relief. Some patients still face persistent symptoms and disability despite treatment, known as refractory CIDP. 

Our presentations at #PNS2025 focus on exploring the underlying mechanisms of CIDP to advance treatments that help people live for the moment, not for the disease. Learn more â¡ï¸ http://spkl.io/6040f2yHY

Diseases that are rare, need much more care.

How easy is it for you to raise your hands above your head? Or sit cross-legged?

Imagine needing assistance for these basic movements - privileges of a healthy body most people often take for granted. 

Meet Sumair, living with Mucopolysaccharidosis I (MPS I), a rare genetic disorder that significantly impacted his mobility, causing excruciating pain in his legs. Despite symptoms appearing in early childhood, his diagnosis took an agonizing 14 years. 

Through enzyme replacement therapy, Sumairâ€™s life took a 180-degrees turn - reducing pain and enabling him to pursue his passion as a musician.

For people living with rare diseases such as MPS I, the path from symptoms to treatment is often arduous. Correct medical intervention at the right time can be life-changing, which is why we have consistently focused our efforts on raising awareness on timely genetic testing. Furthermore, our India Charitable Access Program (part of Sanofiâ€™s Global Humanitarian Program) provides free treatment for over 130 people living with rare diseases in India.

On International MPS Day today, we take the opportunity to shine light on the criticality of early diagnosis and timely treatment of rare diseases. 

Watch Sumair's inspiring journey in this video.

Dr Nishant SinghParameshwaran Sitaram Abhishek Banerjee Vinifer Gandhi
Dr. Mayur Shah Keya Kulkarni #SanofiIndia #InternationalMPSAwarenessDay #RareDiseases #Sanofi

As World Immunization Week 2025 draws to a close, we're thrilled to expand the strategic partnership between Sanofi Healthcare India Private Limited and Dr. Reddy's Laboratories to introduce BeyfortusÂ®, Sanofiâ€™s novel drug, in India.

BeyfortusÂ® contains the monoclonal antibody, nirsevimab, in a prefilled injection used for the prevention of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) lower respiratory tract disease (LRTD) in newborns and infants born during or entering their first RSV season. It is also administered in children up to 24 months of age, who remain vulnerable to severe RSV disease through their second RSV season.

Nitya Padmanabhan, Head of Sanofi Vaccines (India) says, â€œBringing BeyfortusÂ® to India is a pivotal step in our mission to protect every child from immunization preventable diseases like RSV. In India, where the disease burden is significant and early protection is critical, this collaboration with Dr. Reddyâ€™s enables us to reach parents and healthcare providers with an innovative solution. Diseases that are rare, need much more care â€“ and February is apt for bringing this subject to the center. While living with a rare disease sounds isolated, and is as tough now, as it has been in the past. 

With most health and support systems designed for more common conditions, people living with a rare disease often face inequities in accessing diagnosis, care, and treatments. 

To commemorate Rare Disease Day 2025 (last day of February) through this week, we will pay tribute to the rare disease community by championing the need for equity for individuals worldwide affected by rare disorders, so they may live fuller lives.

Elevating equity in rare disease continues to be a top priority, as many within this community are often under-heard, under-represented and under-served.

See the story of Lavanya from India and how she battled hard times, to make her way through living a near-normal life! Stay tuned this week, as we shine the light on more such stories of strength...because #EveryLifeIsPrecious

Sanofi Taiwan Wins Double Honors at the National Innovation Awards 

Sanofi Taiwan, which has been in Taiwan for 40 years, has won double honors at the National Innovation Awards with the factor VIII treatment for hemophilia and RSV monoclonal antibody.

The National Innovation Award is the highest benchmark award in Taiwan's biomedical and healthcare industry. It is also a key indicator of international companies' commitment to Taiwan and the enhancement of local and clinical collaboration. The National Innovation Award evaluation committee is composed of 90 top scientific research experts, clinical physicians, and other important professionals. Sanofi Taiwan was recognized by the committee this time, with the comments mentioning that the factor VIII treatment for hemophilia is developed to address the unmet need of existing treatments, breaking through the ceiling effect of vWF, with the half-life extended by 3 to 4 times compared to existing treatments. The RSV monoclonal antibody is suitable for all infant protection, and clinical trials and real-world data in western countries have shown significant efficacy and effectiveness against RSV, demonstrating good safety as well.

Winning the National Innovation Award is a recognition of Sanofi Taiwan's years of efforts in pharmaceutical research and innovation. Sanofi continues to commit to Taiwan, establishing partnership with medical and academic institutions to jointly medical innovation.

With SK bioscience weâ€™ve exciting news to share! We're actively working to ensure fair labor conditions on farms around the world, tackling systemic challenges like child labor and wage compliance head-on.

Four years ago, two vegetable seed industry leaders and a global human rights organization joined forces, with a goal to collectively address the challenges of child labor, promote minimum wage compliance, and make the sector more gender equal.

This collective effort sparked the Wage Improvements in Seed Hybrids (WISH) initiative, which has since gained momentum, with more seed companies joining the program. Together weâ€™re helping create a blueprint to address inequalities and ensure workers in the seed sector (who often perform physically demanding and repetitive tasks) are treated with dignity and respect.

OurÂ Syngenta Vegetable SeedsÂ team is proud to partner withÂ BASF | Nunhems,Â Arisa,Â HM.CLAUSE,Â Enza Zaden, andÂ Seedworks International Ltd.(Formerly SeedWorks International Pvt. Ltd.)Â on this critical social impact initiative.

Beijing, China ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡³ | Strengthening Agri Ties Between Pakistan and China

Syngenta Pakistan organized a meeting between the Government of Punjab delegation and Syngenta Group China, during the delegationâ€™s official visit to China.

The Punjab Government delegation, led by Syed Ashiq Hussain Kirmani (Minister Agriculture), Iftikhar Ali Sahoo (Secretary Agriculture), and Usama Leghari (Parliamentary Secretary Agriculture), was joined by senior officials from the department.

Representatives from the Pakistan Embassy in Beijing, including Aslam Chaudhary (Economic Minister) and Khan Muhammad Wazir (Counselor), also attended.

The Syngenta Group China delegation was led by Fu Su (President, Syngenta Group China) and Vivian Hou (Chief Sustainability Officer).

From Syngenta Pakistan, the participants included Zeeshan Hasib Baig (Country GM) and Syed M. Ali Murtaza (Head of Corporate Affairs & Sustainability).

The engagement focused on food security challenges amid climate change, with discussions centered on introducing climate-resilient seeds and modern agricultural technologies in Pakistan. As a global leader in agri-tech, Syngenta Group is well-positioned to support Pakistanâ€™s efforts to modernize its agriculture sector.

Syngenta Group China, through Syngenta Pakistan, will continue to collaborate closely with the Government of Punjab to build a strong partnership for sustainable growth.

While in Beijing, Syngenta Pakistanâ€™s Head of Corporate Affairs & Sustainability, Syed Ali Murtaza, also called on Pakistanâ€™s Ambassador to China, H.E. Khalil Hashmi.

Today is World Diabetes Day (WDD), a moment to reflect on one of the most pressing public health challenges of our times. 

India is at the heart of this issue as it features in the top three countries with the highest estimated incidence as ~90 million Indians live with diabetes*. These figures underscore the urgent need for greater awareness, early diagnosis and adoption of a healthy lifestyle.

At Sanofi, weâ€™re committed to empowering people with verified information so that they can eat right and live active. In commemoration of WDD, we planned several strategic media engagements on diabetes awareness.

1. Expert Insights: Dr. Arvind Gadekarâ€™s article in today's The Times Of India (TOI) Mumbai edition offers practical guidance on diabetes prevention and management. Read the attached article to learn more.

2. Sanofi Diabetes Dialogues: This educational webinar features leading experts answering FAQs on diabetes and dispelling insulin myths, streamed TOIâ€™s Facebook handle today. Watch it here: http://spkl.io/6048AjVS8 

3. Kids and Diabetes in Schools (KiDS): This CSR program by the International Diabetes Federation (IDF), supported by Sanofi, transforms how children, parents, and teachers approach diabetes by tackling taboos and promoting healthy lifestyles.

i.	A film on NDTV's "The Changemakers" showcases the impact of the KiDS program across schools in Goa and UP, educating the next generation about diabetes prevention. Watch it here: http://spkl.io/6049AjVSD 

ii.	A panel discussion with an eminent endocrinologist and school principal from Goa aired today on Prudent Media , demonstrating how KiDS transforms children's understanding of nutrition. Watch here: http://spkl.io/6040AjVSE 

This World Diabetes Day, letâ€™s raise our voices and work together to build a future where diabetes care is accessible, compassionate, and empowering.

On World Diabetes Day, we join the International Diabetes Federation (IDF) in highlighting this yearâ€™s theme: â€˜Diabetes and the workplaceâ€™.

Diabetes is one of the most pressing health challenges of our time, experienced by 589 million people worldwide and shaping lives far beyond the clinic. Weâ€™ve officially entered the â€œEpithelial Eraâ€ of upper airway science. 

Research shows that in conditions like chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps (#CRSwNP) and severe #asthma, symptoms typically begin with inflammation in the airway epithelium.  

At Amgen, we are committed to translating these scientific insights into meaningful progress for people living with chronic airway diseases.

Amgen is expanding its biotech innovation footprint in San Francisco with two floors of advanced R&D lab space designed to accelerate small molecule drug discovery.

By bringing together medicinal chemists, computational and structural biologists, protein scientists, and bioassay experts, weâ€™re fostering deeper collaboration to drive faster innovation.

This investment reinforces our leadership in research and development and deepens our commitment to science that serves patients.

ğŸ”¬ A new option for the add-on maintenance treatment of adult and pediatric patients aged 12 years and older with inadequately controlled chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps (CRSwNP) has been approved in the U.S.

This milestone advances care for an often-overlooked condition and highlights the scientific shift toward recognizing #CRSwNP as an epithelial-driven disease, not just as a localized sinus condition.

With this approval in CRSwNP, we are entering a pivotal new chapter in inflammatory research. Amgen remains committed to working with experts to raise awareness and support for people living with this condition.

What if you could lock disease biology into place? ğŸ”  

Amgen scientists are pioneering a potential new way to treat disease with LOCKTAC molecular glues that lock proteins together to control biological activity.  

AMG 193 is one example of a LOCKTAC glue that is designed to selectively target tumor cells that have lost a gene called MTAP, with the goal of sparing healthy tissue. This potential first-in-class molecule is now in clinical trials.

Living with a rare disease like vasculitis isnâ€™t easy. Stacy knows that all too well. â¤ï¸ 

ANCA-associated #vasculitis (AAV) is an autoimmune disease affecting key organs throughout the body. For Stacy, this condition brought misdiagnoses, relentless symptoms, and confusion over where to turn for support. 

But instead of waiting for answers, Stacy chose to take control, tracking symptoms, diving into research, and preparing for every appointment with questions that mattered. By doing so, she actively reshaped her care. 

During #VAM2025 especially, her story is a powerful reminder that self-advocacy can change the trajectory of living with a rare disease like AAV. Your voice can change everything.

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is a rare immune disorder that makes it harder to fight certain infections. 

While itâ€™s more likely to be diagnosed in men, women can be X-linked #CGD carriersâ€”and theyâ€™re not always symptom-free. 

A recent JACI study revealed that female carriers can develop serious infections and inflammatory conditions. Thatâ€™s why regular monitoring matters, even without symptoms.

This #PrimaryImmunodeficiencyMonth, weâ€™re raising awareness, investing in research, and partnering with experts to better understand and support women with X-linked CGD.

Despite affecting 1 in 5 people worldwide, high Lipoprotein(a) is an underdiagnosed and emerging risk factor for cardiovascular disease. 

Unlike LDL cholesterol, up to 90% of a personâ€™s Lp(a) level is genetically inherited and therefore cannot be managed effectively through lifestyle changes. 

Despite its role in cardiovascular disease, high Lp(a) is often missed in routine clinical practice, as many standard lipid panels do not measure it. 

At Amgen, we are committed to advancing cardiovascular care by supporting awareness, innovation, and action. 

This #LpaAwarenessDay, let's close the gap in cardiovascular risk assessment and empower patients with the knowledge they need.

Stay Alert: Protect Yourself from Hiring Scams

We continue to see an alarming rise in increasingly sophisticated recruiting scams targeting job seekers. At Regeneron, your safety and security are top priorities, and we want to ensure youâ€™re informed and protected. Here's what you need to know:

Key Details to Watch For:
- You receive an email claiming to be from a legitimate recruiter at a reputable company.
- Upon closer inspection, the email address is a non-corporate domain.
- The â€œrecruiterâ€ references specific details from your LinkedIn profile, making the communication seem authentic.
- They share a link to a real job posting and ask for your resume once you express interest.
- After reviewing your resume, they claim discrepancies between your LinkedIn profile and resume could hinder your chances of success.
- They then offer to connect you with a â€œprofessional resume writerâ€ for a small fee to â€œfixâ€ the issue.

Important Reminders:
- Legitimate recruiters will always use official company email addresses (e.g., @regeneron.com).
- Real recruiters will never create fear or doubt about your qualifications.
- Authentic recruiters will never recommend or require paid services of any kind.

This type of scam is distressing for everyone involved, and we urge you to remain vigilant. If you encounter suspicious communications, verify their authenticity by reaching out to us directly: https://lnkd.in/efiFcp2a.

Stay diligent and feel free to comment below with any other #hiringscam tactics youâ€™ve seen so we can continue to educate and protect our community.

Today, in recognition of #WorldObesityDay, Regeneron continues to work on innovative solutions to help reduce the rates of obesity.â€¯ 

Recent advancements in the treatment of obesity have made significant strides in helping people lose weightâ€”but it often comes at a cost: a loss of muscle mass, which can have a negative impact on metabolic health and overall physical fitness.â€¯ 

Our years of research and subsequent scientific discoveries around muscle and metabolism have led us to focus our research efforts on a muscle preservation approach with a goal to help preserve or even grow muscle during periods of caloric restriction. With these innovative approaches, Regeneron is striving to shift the conversation around weight loss so itâ€™s not just about quantity, but quality, too.

Scale and depth of data can help us identify drivers of disease. This week, we joined the UK Biobankâ€™s Pharma Proteomics Project â€” the most comprehensive study of human proteins to date, with the potential to transform therapeutics and patient care. In addition to being one of 14 biopharmaceutical co-funding consortium members, Regeneron Genetics Center (RGC) was also selected to conduct all the protein sequencing.

CMV Awareness Month in June highlights the impact of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV), the most common congenital infection worldwide, affecting 1 in 200 newborns in the US and up to 12 in 200 in developing countries. As part of Modernaâ€™s #StimulatingtheScience initiative, weâ€™re recognizing peer-reviewed studies that are shaping the future of CMV awareness, surveillance and care.
Â 
The second article weâ€™re proud to highlight this month is by Dr. Chelsea Lutz, PhD, MPH, CPH, et al., and is titled, â€œUpdated National and State-Specific Prevalence of Congenital Cytomegalovirus Infection, United States, 2018â€“2022â€

This study presents the most recent national and state-specific estimates of congenital CMV (cCMV) prevalence in the U.S., adjusted for maternal age and demographic differences across populations. The findings reveal clear health disparities in cCMV burden by race, ethnicity, maternal age and geographyâ€”insights that are critical for informing more targeted and equitable public health strategies, screening programs and future vaccine efforts.
Â 
We thank the authors for their important contributions to the field that support efforts to reduce the burden of cCMV nationwide.

June is CMV Awareness Monthâ€”a time dedicated to raising awareness about cytomegalovirus (CMV), the leading infectious cause of birth defects in the United States. As part of this effort, our #StimulatingtheScience initiative recognizes and celebrates important, peer-reviewed research that advances our understanding of CMV and supports efforts to improve prevention, diagnosis and care.
Â 
The first study we are recognizing for our initiative is by Dr. Mallory Baker, et al., and is titled, â€œTiming of Congenital Cytomegalovirus Diagnosis and Missed Opportunitiesâ€.

This study sheds light on how delayed diagnoses of congenital CMV (cCMV) can result in missed opportunities for early treatment, monitoring and intervention. Nearly half of the infants in the cohort were not diagnosed until after 3 weeks of age, with some diagnoses occurring well after the onset of sensorineural hearing loss. The findings emphasize the importance of early screening strategiesâ€”including universal and expanded targeted approachesâ€”to prevent diagnostic delays and improve developmental outcomes.
Â 
We thank Dr. Baker and her colleagues for their meaningful contribution to the field and for helping shape the case for improved cCMV detection and care pathways.

Read the study: https://lnkd.in/eA3Vqrvx

Farmers canâ€™t control the weather, but they can choose how to respond to it. âš¡ï¸

Crops like wheat, soy, and corn often show early signs of drought stress, and without timely intervention, these plants will wither, deprived of the nutrients they need to thrive. But what if we could make these crops more resilient to drought?

This World Day to Combat Desertification and Drought, we're sharing how new technologies can make crops more resilient with the power of science. Our agronomists have observed that certain classes of fungicides can improve the yield of these crops, both in the presence of biotic stress caused by pathogens and of abiotic stress from environmental conditions like heat or drought.

In these sample images, untreated corn shows stunted kernel development, with dry, discoloured silksâ€”all signs of water stress in pollination. By contrast, the treated crop appears fuller and healthier.

Today at the Forum for the Future of Agriculture in Brussels, Syngenta Group Chief Sustainability Officer, Petra Laux, shared Syngenta's vision for the future of European agriculture.
Â 
"Syngenta is pleased to see farmers placed at the center of the EUâ€™s vision for agriculture. We've reached a pivotal moment for European farming, and we need to chart a path forward that combines food sustainability with competitiveness," Petra emphasized during the panel discussion on the EU's Vision for Agriculture and Food.
Â 
Petra outlined three critical areas to empower farmers in this transformation:

1) Biocontrols: We welcome the Commissionâ€™s plan for fast-track approvals for biocontrols but advocate for dedicated legislation to address this regulatory bottleneck and accelerate access to innovation to give farmers more sustainable, productive solutions.

2) Seed technology: Modern technologies can develop high-yielding crops with superior nutritional value that can be grown more resource-efficiently - essential for meeting both ecological and economic goals.

3) Digital agriculture: From AI to data analytics, digital solutions can swiftly improve farm economic performance, resilience, and sustainability through precision agriculture techniques.
Â 
We can only achieve our goals by embracing innovation and supporting farmers in their day-to-day reality. Through this, we can ensure European agriculture remains competitive while transitioning from being a climate problem to a climate solution.

Syngenta Pakistan goes solar reaffirming its commitment to sustainable business practices

More than a decade ago, Syngenta Group was one of the first companies in the industry to launch a plan that served as the organizationâ€™s sustainability compass. With the global population on track to reach 9.7 billion by 2050, farmers need to grow more food while reducing their impact on the environment and safeguarding natural resources.

Syngenta aims to reduce the intensity of its footprint by 68 percent based on value added by 2030 compared to the 2016 baseline. This target is consistent with reductions required to limit global warming to well below 2Â°C compared to pre-industrial levels. To achieve the 2030 carbon intensity reduction target, Syngenta is focusing on improving the efficiency of its manufacturing processes, designing and implementing site-based energy-saving programs, increasing the share of renewable sources of energy, and partnering with its crop protection and seed suppliers to reduce their carbon footprint. The environmental sustainability requirements outlined in the HSE Code of Practice on Environmental Sustainability ensure that Syngenta operations are aware of their resources usage and implement programs to conserve natural resources, minimize environmental impact, and adopt more sustainable practices. These requirements cover various aspects of environmental sustainability, including greenhouse gas emissions reduction and optimizing logistics network.

Syngenta Pakistan is fully aligned with Syngenta Groupâ€™s sustainability vision.Â Syngentaâ€™s supply chain accounts for about 90 percent of Syngentaâ€™s total carbon footprint, while 10 percent of emissions come from Syngentaâ€™s operations. Focusing on reducing the GHG emissions Syngenta, Pakistan embarked on a mission to convert their manufacturing facility in Karachi and their warehouses across the country including Lahore, Multan and Rahimyar Khan onto solar energy. Syngenta, Pakistan has installed over 300KW of solar capacity across its facilities. This initiative has not only helped the business bring down its operational cost but has also helped Syngenta, Pakistan to move onto a renewable source of green energy. 

On inaugurating the solar energy system at Syngentaâ€™s plant in Karachi- Country General Manager- Zeeshan Hasib Baig said â€œThis is an important milestone for Syngenta, Pakistan to be converting its manufacturing facility onto Solar Energy. As a responsible corporate entity Syngenta is committed to playing its part in ensuring sustainable growthâ€.
